This Task illustrates the general result in the following Key Point:

Key Point

Commutativity Property of Convolution

\[(f*g)(t)=(g*f)(t)\] In words: the convolution of \(f(t)\) with \(g(t)\) is the same as the convolution of \(g(t)\) with \(f(t)\).

Example

Obtain the Laplace transforms of \(f(t)=t.u(t)\) and \(g(t)=\sin t.u(t)\) and \((f*g)(t)\).

Solution

Begin by finding \({\cal L}\{f(t)\}\), \({\cal L}\{g(t)\}\):

\[{\cal L}\{f(t)\} ={1\over {s^2}}\qquad {\cal L}\{g(t)\}={1\over {s^2+1}}\]

Now find \({\cal L}\{(f*g)(t)\}\):

From the previous Example \((f*g)(t)=t-\sin t\) and so \[ {\cal L}\{(f*g)(t)\}={\cal L}\{t-\sin t\}={1\over {s^2}}-{1\over {s^2+1}}\]

Now compare \({\cal L}\{f(t)\}\times {\cal L}\{g(t)\}\) with \({\cal L}\{f*g(t)\}\). What do you observe?

\[{\cal L}\{(f*g)(t)\}={1\over {s^2}}-{1\over {s^2+1}}={1\over {s^2}}\left({1\over {s^2+1}}\right) ={\cal L}\{f(t)\}{\cal L}\{g(t)\} =F(s)G(s)\] We see that the Laplace transform of the convolution of \(f(t)\) and \(g(t)\) is the product of their separate Laplace transforms. This, in fact, is a general result which is expressed in the statement of the convolution theorem which we discuss in the next subsection.
